details.title: Reliability Sampling Methodology Using Simulation and Re-Sampling

authors.affiliation: U.S. Army Materiel Syst. Anal. Activity, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD

p: John Nierwinski, Jr. is a Statistician and Operations Research Analyst with the U.S. Army Materiel Systems Analysis Activity (AMSAA) located at Aberdeen Proving Ground (APG), MD. Before working at AMSAA, he was a Statistician and Vice President in the insurance and credit card industries. He received a Masters degree (2005) in Operations Research from Florida Institute of Technology. His research interests include reliability sampling and simulation, process management (tracking, evaluation and quality control), stochastic processes, categorical data analysis, aging analysis, regression analysis, and statistical modeling.

authors.name: John Nierwinski

details.abstract: This paper develops and validates a reliability sampling methodology using simulation, and re-sampling; and which incorporates unit-to-unit variation in the determination of significant sample sizes for analytically intractable reliability cases. This sample size determination is very important because the reliability of the sampled vehicles should represent the reliability of the entire fleet. Smaller-than-required sample sizes may lead to an incorrect representation of the reliability of the fleet, which may mislead the Army to make poor decisions, such as deploying a fleet that may not be reliable. These type II errors can be minimized by incorporating a more realistic sampling methodology, as developed in this research. Prior to using this methodology, analytical formulas were used to compute reliability sample sizes with unit-to-unit variation assumed to be constant. This new methodology confirms the analytically derived solutions for fixed usage & true failure rate, as well as for fixed usage & varying vehicle true failure rate. Existing reliability data shows that unit-to-unit variation does exist. Vehicle variation in true failure rate is modeled with a Gamma prior distribution. Recent reliability data are used to validate the hypothesis that this is an adequate tool for reliability sampling when unit-to-unit variation exists. Results of this validation accept the hypothesis, validating that the methodology is an adequate tool. The Army is currently using this methodology for fleet assessment

context.text: RECAP is a program that rebuilds and/or upgrades systems to like-new condition [1]. “System” refers to the type of vehicle (e.g. tank, m88, etc.).

references.text: LTG P. J. Kern, "Supporting efforts critical to the army's transformation \$ldots\$ recapitalization and unit set fielding", Army AL&T, JanuaryFebruary 2001.

references.title: Sampling Techniques

context.text: The following approximate sample size formula can be derived assuming constant true failure rate \$(\lambda)\$, constant mileage (T), and the number of failures for each vehicle is Poisson [2]:If \$N\$ is very large, the sample size converges to.

It can be shown that the distribution for the number of failures of the entire fleet of vehicles is Negative Binomial [3] with \${\rm mean} =\overline{X}\$, and \${\rm variance}={\rm Var}=\overline{X}+\overline{X}/\alpha\$ (where \$\alpha\$ is the shape parameter of the Gamma prior distribution); and that the following approximate sample size formula can be derived [2]:If \$N\$ is very large, then the approximate sample size converges to.

references.text: W. G. Cochran, Sampling Techniques, 1977, John Wiley & Sons.

context.text: It can be shown that the distribution for the number of failures of the entire fleet of vehicles is Negative Binomial [3] with \${\rm mean} =\overline{X}\$, and \${\rm variance}={\rm Var}=\overline{X}+\overline{X}/\alpha\$ (where \$\alpha\$ is the shape parameter of the Gamma prior distribution); and that the following approximate sample size formula can be derived [2]:If \$N\$ is very large, then the approximate sample size converges to.

references.title: An Introduction to the Bootstrap

context.text: Bootstrapping [4] is defined as randomly sampling \$n\$ times, with replacement, from the original existing data points \$t_{1}, t_{2}, \ldots, t_{n}\$.
Hence, because this estimation problem is nonparametric, bootstrapping is a good choice for estimation [4].

references.text: B. Efron, R. Tibshirani, An Introduction to the Bootstrap, 1998, Chapman & Hall/CRC.

references.title: Bayesian Reliability Analysis

context.text: The Gamma prior distribution will be considered for estimating failure rate \$(\lambda_{j})\$ variation from unit to unit because it is highly recommended by reliability experts for reliability applications, and because of its flexibility [5].
This estimation approach is a well documented [5], highly applied [6], [7], non-Bayesian approach, sometimes referred to as the parametric empirical Bayes (PEB) approach.
Two methods are used to estimate these parameters using the PEB approach: the Method of Moments, and the Marginal Maximum Likelihood [5].
The respective weighted moment estimators for \$\alpha\$, and \$\beta\$ become [5] and.
The respective likelihood equations are [5] andEquations (3), and (4) must be iteratively solved to obtain the ML estimates \$\mathhat{\alpha}\$, and \$\mathhat{\beta}\$.

references.text: H. F. Martz, R. A. Waller, Bayesian Reliability Analysis, 1982, John Wiley & Sons.

references.title:
Exponential order statistic models of software
reliability growth

context.text: This estimation approach is a well documented [5], highly applied [6], [7], non-Bayesian approach, sometimes referred to as the parametric empirical Bayes (PEB) approach.

links.abstract: Failure times of a software reliability growth process are modeled as order statistics of independent, nonidentically distributed exponential random variables. The Jelinsky-Moranda, Goel-Okumoto, Littlewood, Musa-Okumoto logarithmic, and power law models are all special cases of exponential order statistic models, but there are many additional examples as well. Various characterizations, properties, and examples of this class of models are developed and presented.

references.text: D. Miller, "Exponential order statistic models of software reliability growth", IEEE Trans. Software Engineering, vol. SE-12, no. 1, 1986.

references.title: Bayes attribute acceptance-sampling plan

context.text: This estimation approach is a well documented [5], highly applied [6], [7], non-Bayesian approach, sometimes referred to as the parametric empirical Bayes (PEB) approach.

links.abstract: The authors briefly review an approach for choosing a prior distribution for a Bayes attribute (good/bad) acceptance-sampling plan. A prior is chosen from confidence levels corresponding to classical lower confidence bounds. Where a Bayes plan is acceptable, the sample size can be reduced.

references.text: Z. Sheng, D. Fan, "Bayes attribute acceptance-sampling plan", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 41, pp. 307-309, June 1992.

references.title: Statistical Methods for Reliability Data

context.text: MTBF is defined as the mean time between failures, and 1/MTBF is the failure rate [8].

references.text: W. Q. Meeker, L. A. Escobar, Statistical Methods for Reliability Data, 1998, John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

references.title: Simulation Modeling and Analysis

context.text: A simulation model that is validated using actual data is considered to be a credible simulation model, and serves as a good representation of reality [9].

references.text: A. M. Law, W. D. Kelton, Simulation Modeling and Analysis, 2000, McGraw Hill.

references.title: Introduction to Probability Models

links.abstract: The author examines both strategic and detailed issues of applying computer technology in projects to help ensure that the benefits afforded by the technology can be fully realised. The author discusses the technology issues, the system strategy and development, and the benefits of applying computer technology to project management. The author then discusses the project phases and their implementation.

references.text: S. M. Ross, Introduction to Probability Models, 2003, Academic Press.

references.title: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
references.text: R. V. Hogg, A. T. Craig, Introduction to Mathematical Statistics, 1978, Macmillan Publishing Co.
